newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Hong Kong unveils model for new companies law.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong unveils model for new companies law.

text.p: Hong Kong has taken the first step toward drafting a modern, streamlined Companies Ordinance, senior government officials and legal consultants said on Thursday.

"We are proposing a new model for the framework for the Companies Ordinance in Hong Kong...using international benchmarkets in companies law," said consultant Cally Jordon, former assistant professor at the Faculty of Law at McGill University, Montreal, at a news conference called to present the consultants' report.

The consultants in their Review of the Hong Kong Companies Ordinance said they had adopted a core company law approach which moved away from the complicated British-style legislation toward a simple Commonwealth model.
The report recommended an unbundling of the non-core legislation included in the current Companies Ordinance, such as legislation on securities and bankruptcy.
"If we take out the solvency law, it will reduce the Hong Kong company's law by one-third," said Jordan.
The review recommended the insolvency provisions of the companies ordinance and the bankruptcy ordinance be combined in a separate, comprehensive Insolvency Ordinance.

The report also recommended a single regime for both public and private companies, one which focuses on providing a simple, efficient and cost effective method of incorporation and ongoing corporate maintenance.
The recommendations also provide a framework for a new law which was more applicable to Hong Kong, where nearly 99 percent of incorporations are private companies, the report said.
Hong Kong's current ordinance was originally drafted with 19th century public companies in mind, the report said.

One of the objectives of a Companies Ordinance in Hong Kong should be "to be enabling and permissive rather than regulating and prohibitive and to refrain from being a vehicle for implementation of industrial relations, tax, social or monetary policy," the consultants' report said.

"We believe that our recommendations are consistent with the Hong Kong government's noninterventionist, free market economy," said Ermanno Pascutto, former deputy chairman of the Securities and Futures Commission, who led the study.
In common law countries, the companies law had a profit-making focus and this was still the case in the Hong Kong recommendations, the consultants said.
The consultants' review took slightly more than two years to complete.

The Standing Committee on Company Law Reform, a non-statutory body which advises the Financial Secretary, would begin a 12-month examination of the consultants' report on May 3, said G.W. Jones, registrar of companies.
A public consultation period will be held simultaneously with the standing committee's review.
The consultants said the entire process of drafting and enacting a new companies law would take five to seven years.
